text:
Neither does it frighten me.

After the rain, I went back into the field of sunflowers.
It was cool, and I was anything but drowsy.
I walked slowly, and listened

to the crazy roots, in the drenched earth, laughing and growing.

—sometimes, Mary Oliver
author: JNSmall

text:
Let the cathead appear again-
the smallest of your mysteries,
some wild cousin of my own blood probably-
some cousin of my own wild blood probably,
in the black dinner-bowl of the pond.

7.
Death waits for me, I know it, around
one corner or another.
This doesn’t amuse me.
author: JNSmall

text:
6.
God, rest in my heart
and fortify me,
take away my hunger for answers,
let the hours play upon my body

like the hands of my beloved.
author: JNSmall

text:
5.
Two or three times in my life I discovered love.
Each time it seemed to solve everything.
Each time it solved a great many things
but not everything.
Yet left me as grateful as if it had indeed, and
thoroughly, solved everything.
author: JNSmall

text:
4.

Instructions for living a life:
Pay attention.
Be astonished.
Tell about it.
author: JNSmall

text:
3.

Water from the heavens! Electricity from the source!
Both of them mad to create something!

The lighting brighter than any flower.
The thunder without a drowsy bone in its body.
author: JNSmall

text:
But I believe they have between them
some fervent and necessary arrangement.

2.

Sometime
melancholy leaves me breathless…
author: JNSmall

text:
1.

Something came up
out of the dark.
It wasn’t anything I had ever seen before.
It wasn’t an animal
or a flower,
unless it was both.

Something came up out of the water,
a head the size of a cat
but muddy and without ears.
I don’t know what God is.
I don’t know what death is.
author: JNSmall

text: My take on Sandra Day O’Connor:

text: Sandra Day O'Connor announces she likely has Alzheimer's. Makes me wonder if there was an environmental trigger if both she and her husband had it. Most people don't realize the majority of Alzheimer's is environmental, we just don't know what's causing it

text: 2/2 Well, maybe not always. He did sometimes get mad at me for things I’d written and refuse to speak to me for a few months. But he eventually forgave me and I always learned from whatever he had to say. He had a way of seeing to the heart of an issue, straight talk indeed.
author: JNSmall

text: RIP John McCain. This is the end of an era in the Senate. McCain reached across the aisle to form amigos, gangs and legislation. He was always willing to talk & listen to colleagues, to journalists, to people. 1/2
author: JNSmall

text: RIP Kofi Annan. My father worked with him in Addis Ababa in the 1960's. I knew him my whole life. I'd sometimes ask him to tell me stories about my dad. I'll miss not only the great man & Secretary General, but another keeper of my father's memories as we lost him to Alzheimer's
